creditline: Gift of Bill and Roberta Stein
markings: BL below image, graphite: tc; BLC, graphite: 32; verso BRC, graphite: 151993-202 / VCR 169-7 / HAM 910145
text: A mezzotint is made by using a tool called a rocker to make small repetitive marks on the surface on a copper plate. The artist then smooths or scrapes down areas to create the design. When printed, the areas that were initially scratched with the rocker produce a velvety black, while the areas that were polished print lighter. Hamaguchi took advantage of the fuzzy appearance of the mezzotint, and further devised a way to add color—black, blue, red, and yellow. The colors of these cherries are the result of just four colors.
title: Twenty-Two Cherries
